Maike Rossmann

  • Endereço para acessar este CV: http://lattes.cnpq.br/6839732059706744
  • Última atualização do currículo em 04/06/2018

Sou profissional graduada em Ciências Biológicas (licenciatura e bacharelado) pelas Faculdades Integradas São Pedro (2004), especialista em Biotecnologia pela Universidade Federal do Espírito Santo (2005), com mestrado em Microbiologia (2008) e Doutorado na área de Engenharia Agrícola (2011), ambos pela Universidade Federal de Viçosa. Possuo conhecimento em rotinas laboratoriais das áreas de microbiologia e biotecnologia, gestão de pessoas e equipes, gestão de laboratório, além de experiência na elaboração de relatórios e artigos científicos. As áreas de maior conhecimento são: Microbiologia e Ecologia, com ênfase em microbiologia do solo, comunidade microbiana rizosférica, metagenômica, otimização de processos e tratamento de águas residuárias (Texto informado pelo autor)

Projetos de pesquisa
2018 - Atual
Microbial diversity in plants and crop soils
Descrição: Microorganisms play an essential role in terrestrial ecosystems, including soil fertility, residue decomposition and nutrient cycling. Despite its importance, studies about interactions between soils, plants and microorganisms are rare but essential for understanding ecosystem dynamics. Based on this, the project aims (i) to uncover the microbial diversity in soils under different crops, (ii) to disentail the microbial community structure in the bulk soil, rhizosphere and internal plant tissues (endophytes) and (iii) to evaluate how a set of physicochemical parameters may influence shifts in the microbial communities in these areas. For this, we will use leaves, roots and soils under corn and soybean crops, collected in eight different areas in Brazil. We expect to improve the knowledge on soil process, which in turns is essential to implementing the adoption and economics of precision agriculture management, by promoting the growth of beneficial microbial functioning related to improvements in plant development..
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Maike Rossmann - Integrante / João Carlos Setubal - Coordenador / Aline Maria da Silva - Integrante.
2016 - Atual
Exploitation of the rhizosphere microbiome for a sustainable wheat production
Descrição: Plants are colonized by an astounding number of microorganisms that can reach cell densities much greater than the number of plant cells. Recent research has found that soil microbes benefit crop plants in a number of ways, including improved plant nutritional status and disease suppression. However, the exact nature of these communities and the microbial partners required are poorly understood, let alone the mechanisms by which they benefit host plants. As such, it is important that we determine how the soil microbial community influences wheat plant health to achieve sustainable intensification of production. Determining the optimum composition of soil microbiomes associated with plants, especially the root systems (the rhizosphere), to inform sustainable soil management strategies represents a novel and unique strategy to boost plant growth and health that has not previously been attempted. The rhizosphere microbiome can provide a range of functions to sustain plant development, such as: nitrogen fixation, nutrient solubilisation or defence against pathogens. However, elucidation of the mechanisms underlying beneficial interactions between microbes and plants are not well understood. Understanding these mechanisms will be key to optimising the rhizosphere microbiome for sustainable wheat production, and is central to the work planned in this proposal. In this project, we will elucidate the relative importance of the host plant (both modern and ancestral wheat) in terms of genotype and root chemistry, as well as farming practices such as crop rotation and fertilisation regime, in shaping the wheat rhizosphere microbiome. The microbiome will be assessed using meta-genomic and meta-transcriptomic techniques, whereas the plant host genotype will be determined using diversity arrays technology and plant root chemistry through metabolomics. We will also identify keystone members of the rhizosphere microbiome through 'proof of principle' experiments to assess how manipulation of the microbiome structure influences plant performance. As such, we will obtain a holistic understanding of the factors influencing the microbiome structure, as well as how the microbiome influences both crop health and yield - both of which are required to optimise microbiome function for enhanced plant production in a sustainable manner...
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Maike Rossmann - Integrante / Ian Clark - Integrante / Penny Hirsch - Integrante / Rodrigo Mendes - Coordenador / Tim Mauchline - Integrante / Vanessa Nessner Kavamura - Integrante / Adhemar Zerlotini Neto - Integrante / Artur Jordão Magalhães Rosa - Integrante / Flávio Martins Santana - Integrante / Jose Pereira da Silva Junior - Integrante / Leandro Carrijo Cintra - Integrante / Poliana Fernanda Giachetto - Integrante / Ricardo de Lima Castro - Integrante / TTammy Aparecida Manabe Kiihl - Integrante.
Financiador(es): Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Research Council - Auxílio financeiro / Brazilian Agricultural Research Corporation - Auxílio financeiro.
2015 - Atual
The rhizosphere microbiome of modern and old wheat cultivars
Descrição: The search for a sustainable agriculture is linked to a reduction in the use of nutrients and chemicals, associated with development of cultivars e productions systems at low environmental costs. Rhizosphere dwellers impact plant growth, nutrition and health, consequently affecting the composition and the biomass of plant communities. Recent studies have shown that plant breeding using modern agricultural practices, which include fertilization for plant nutrition and chemicals for plants protection, possibly led to a selection against plant traits that are essential for the establishment of beneficial microbes in the rhizosphere. In this context, this proposal aims to study the structure and diversity of wheat (Triticum aestivum) microbiome in the rhizosphere, and root and seed endosphere present in modern cultivars and compare with their antecessors. Coupling traditional approaches, which include microbe isolation in media, with advanced molecular techniques, as next generation sequencing, we will get insights on microbial life in the rhizosphere, roots and seeds associated with the host. The outcome of this project will provide advances in the fundamental knowledge related to how plants actively recruit and shape the rhizosphere microbiome and how these microbes support and sustain plant growth and development. Initiatives as the present proposal are needed to promote the discovery and development of new strategies to improve plant growth and health in a sustainable manner..
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Maike Rossmann - Integrante / Victor Satler Pylro - Integrante / Rodrigo Mendes - Coordenador / Tim Mauchline - Integrante / Jos M. Raaijmakers - Integrante.
Financiador(es): Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Científico e Tecnológico - Auxílio financeiro.
